content.p: Joe has just started the Safe Computing unit in C@CM. He wants to get through it as quickly as possible while still making sure he is prepared for the proctored exam in two weeks. He sees a bunch of text with some activities sprinkled throughout and is trying to decide how to proceed.

question.body: Which of the following strategies would likely be most effective and efficient for Joe? (Note: More than one strategy may be effective and efficient).

multiple_choice.choice: Jump straight to the activities without reading the text. For each activity, select different answer choices to see if theyâ€™re right or wrong and read the feedback text that comes up.
Jump straight to the first activity and if he cannot answer it, go back to the beginning of the unit to read the text.
Jump straight to the activities and after realizing that he has no idea how to answer the first few, quit out of the course and plan to attend his C@CM support meeting that week.
Read the unit straight through from the beginning and do the activities as they come up.
Read the unit straight through from the beginning but skip the activities.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Learning by doing can be a good idea. However, Joe should keep in mind that the feedback for correct and incorrect answers is not as complete as the preceding text, so he might be missing important information.

Correct. The good thing about this strategy is that Joe uses the activities as a way to assess his own capabilities and then adjusts his approach accordingly. Moreover, by deciding to go back to read the preceding text, Joe is giving himself a chance to practice independent learning.

Incorrect. This approach is unlikely to be effective, since Joe will not know what questions to ask at the support meeting. It is also not efficient, since going to a support meeting will take more time than simply reading the explanatory content. By seeking help before trying to learn the material himself, Joe misses the chance to practice learning independently.

Correct. This is a good approach unless Joe already knows the unit material fairly well, in which case it is inefficient. The pre-assessments could help him recognize whether he needs to work through the text systematically, focus on specific skills, or skip to the next unit.

Incorrect. Although reading the text will provide Joe with the information content of this module, by skipping the activities he misses the chance to practice using this information and check his understanding.

part.hint: Think about which of these different strategies will be most likely to give Joe (a) all the information he needs for the final exam and (b) opportunities to practice applying that information and check his understanding.
